member.name: T:Kaos.Combinatorics.Combination
member.summary: Represents an ascending sequence of distinct picks from a supplied range.

remarks.para: The defining variables of a combination are n which is the number of possible choices and k which is the number of distinct picks from those choices. When k is less than n, this is a k-combination also known as a pick-combination. Combinations are contrasted to multicombinations where the values in the sequence may repeat.

The class produces k-combinations with ascending elements. While sequence order of the elements is not a general requirement of combinations, producing an ascending sequence allows ranking the sequences into an ordered table.

Use the property to get the number of elements (k) of a taken from a possible number of (n).
Use the property to get the number of distinct possible sequences.
Use the indexer to get a specified element of the sequence.
Use the default enumerator to iterate thru the elements of a .
Use the Permute method to pick objects from a supplied array of choices based on the current sequence.

Use the property to get or set the row index in a lexicographically ordered table of all possible sequences in an ascending order.
Use to iterate thru all possible sequences of the ordered by .
Use to iterate thru every table of all picks in the range (1..).

The default appearance of a row is a list of integers (starting at 0) enclosed in braces. The appearance may be tailored 3 ways:
Map each element to a different value using the default enumerator or the indexer.
Use the Permute method and output the rearranged values.
Define a subclass of and override ToString(). (See for an example.)
For more information about k-combinations, see:

member.summary: Initializes an empty combination instance.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance that is copied from the supplied combination.

member.summary: Initializes a new combination of 0 with the supplied number of elements.
member.param: Number of elements in the sequence.
member.exception: When choices less than 0.

member.name: M:Kaos.Combinatorics.Combination.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new combination of 0 with the supplied number of picks from the supplied number of choices.
member.param: Number of values to pick from.
Number of elements in the sequence.
member.remarks: Supplying a value for choices that is greater than picks will instantiate a k-combination also known as a pick-combination.
member.exception: When negative value supplied; when picks greater than choices.
When the numbers are just too big.

member.name: M:Kaos.Combinatorics.Combination.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int64)
member.summary: Initializes a new combination of the supplied rank with the supplied number of picks from the supplied number of choices.

remarks.para:
Supplying a value for choices that is greater than picks will instantiate a k-combination also known as a pick-combination.
If the supplied rank is out of the range (0..-1), it will be normalized to the valid range. For example, a value of -1 will produce the last row in the ordered table.

member.param: Number of values to pick from.
Number of elements in the sequence.
Row index in the ordered table.
member.exception: When negative value supplied; when picks greater than choices.
When too many choices.

member.name: M:Kaos.Combinatorics.Combination.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Initializes a new combination from elements supplied in source picked from the supplied number of choices.
member.param: Number of values to pick from.
member.remarks: Supplying a value for choices that is greater than the number of elements in source will instantiate a k-combination also known as a pick-combination.
member.exception: When source is null.
When length of source is greater than picks; when source contains invalid data.

member.returns: Sequence value at index.
member.exception: When index not in range (0..-1).

member.name: T:Kaos.Combinatorics.Combinatoric
member.summary: Provides static methods for combinatorics.
member.remarks: This class cannot be instantiated.

member.name: M:Kaos.Combinatorics.Combinatoric.BinomialCoefficient(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the binomial coefficient of the supplied values.
member.returns: The binomial coefficient of n choose k.
member.remarks: The result is equal to row n, column k of Pascal's triangle with counting starting at 0.

example.para: An exception to the above formulas is the special case where the number of elements is 0. While mathematics treats this result as 1 row containing the empty product, this library returns 0 rows.

member.exception: When the numbers are just too big.

member.name: M:Kaos.Combinatorics.Combinatoric.Factorial(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the factorial of the supplied value.

example.para:
The number of rows in a table of n choices is:
Combinatoric.Factorial (n)
The number of rows in a table of k picks from n choices is:
Combinatoric.Factorial (n) / Combinatoric.Factorial (n-k)

An exception to the above formulas is the special case where the number of elements in the permutation is 0. While mathematics treats this result as 1 row containing the empty product, this library returns 0 rows.

member.exception: When value not in range (0..20).

member.name: T:Kaos.Combinatorics.Multicombination
member.summary: Represents an ascending sequence of repeating picks from a supplied range.

remarks.para: The defining variables of a multicombination are n which is the number of possible choices and k which is the number of repeatable picks from those choices. When k is less than n, this is a k-multicombination also known as a k-combination with repetition. Multicombinations are contrasted to combinations where the values in the sequence do not repeat.

The class produces k-multicombinations with ascending elements that may repeat as many as k times. While sequence order of the elements is not a general requirement of multicombinations, producing an ascending sequence allows ranking the rows into an ordered table.

Use the property to get the number of elements (k) of a taken from a possible number of (n). Use the property to get the number of distinct possible sequences.
Use the indexer to get a specified element of the sequence.
Use the default enumerator to iterate thru the elements of a .
Use the Permute method to pick objects from a supplied array of choices based on the current sequence.

Use the property to get or set the row index in a lexicographically ordered table of all possible non-descending sequences.
Use to iterate thru all possible sequences of the ordered by .
Use GetRowsForPicks (startPick, stopPick) to iterate thru every table of all picks in the range (startPick..stopPick).

The default appearance of a row is a list of integers (starting at 0) enclosed in braces. The appearance may be tailored 3 ways:
Map each element to a different value using the default enumerator or the indexer.
Use the Permute method and output the rearranged values.
Define a subclass of and override ToString(). (See the GetRowsForPicks method for an example.)
For more information about k-multicombinations, see:

member.name: T:Kaos.Combinatorics.Permutation
member.summary: Represents a specific arrangement of distinct picks from a supplied range.

remarks.para: The defining variables of a permutation are n which is the number of possible choices and k which is the number of distinct picks from those choices. When k is less than n, this is a k-permutation also known as a variation. Permutations are contrasted to combinations where the arrangement is generally not significant (except for ranking).

The class uses the inherent sequencing of the elements to arrange the rows into an lexicographically ordered table.
Support for k-permutations is provided by supplying a picks value that is less than the supplied choices value to the appropriate constructors.

Use the property to get the number of elements to choose from.
Use the property to get the number of elements of a .
Use the property to get the number of distinct possible sequences of a .
Use the indexer to get a specified element of the sequence.
Use the default enumerator to iterate thru the elements of a .
Use the Permute method to rearrange a supplied array based on the current sequence.

Use the property to get or set the row index in a lexicographically ordered table of all possible sequences.
Use to iterate thru all possible sequences of the ordered by .
Use to iterate thru every table of all choices in the range (1..).
Use to iterate thru every table of all picks in the range (1..).

Use the property to get or set the row index in a table ordered for plain changes where adjacent rows differ by only a single swap of 2 adjacent elements.
Use to iterate thru all possible sequences of a ordered by .

Use the property to get the number of element swaps that would transform a row into the sequence of 0.
Use the Backtrack method to minimally advance while changing a specified element.

The default appearance of a row is a list of integers (starting at 0) enclosed in braces. The appearance may be tailored 3 ways:
Map each element to a different value using the default enumerator or the indexer.
Use the Permute method and output the rearranged values.
Define a subclass of and override ToString(). (See for an example.)
For more information about permutations and k-permutations, see:

member.exception: When picks less than 0 or greater than choices; when choices greater than 20.

member.summary: Initializes a new permutation of the supplied rank with the supplied number of picks from the supplied number of choices.

remarks.para: Supplying a value for choices that is greater than picks will instantiate a k-permutation also known as a variation.
If rank is out of the range (0..-1), it will be normalized to the valid range. For example, a value of -1 will produce the last row in the ordered table.

member.param: Number of values to choose from.

Row index in the ordered table.
member.example: This is an example of a k-permutation.

member.name: P:Kaos.Combinatorics.Permutation.Choices
member.summary: Number of available choices for the elements of the .
member.remarks: If no picks value was specified when constructing this , then this is also the number of elements.

member.name: P:Kaos.Combinatorics.Permutation.Picks
member.summary: Number of elements in the .
member.remarks: Also known as k. If value is less than Choices, this is a k-permutation.

member.name: P:Kaos.Combinatorics.Permutation.PlainRank
member.summary: Row index of the sequence in the plain ordered table.

remarks.para: Plain changes produces a table where adjacent rows differ by only a single swap of 2 adjacent elements. The table always begins with the same row that begins the lexicographically ordered table of the same .
Any assigned value out of range will be normalized to (0..-1).

member.exception: When Choices not equal to Picks.

member.name: P:Kaos.Combinatorics.Permutation.Rank
member.summary: Row index of the sequence in the lexicographically ordered table.
member.remarks: Any assigned value out of range will be normalized to (0..-1).

member.name: P:Kaos.Combinatorics.Permutation.RowCount
member.summary: Returns number of distinct possible arrangements of this .

member.name: P:Kaos.Combinatorics.Permutation.Swaps
member.summary: Returns number of element swaps needed to transform this into 0.

remarks.para: If additional swaps are applied resulting again in a row of 0, those additional swaps will always be a multiple of 2.
Any with a of 0 always has a of 0.

member.name: M:Kaos.Combinatorics.Permutation.Backtrack(System.Int32)
member.summary: Advance a minimum while changing element at nodeIndex.
member.returns: Lowest index of actual changed element if successful; else -1.
member.remarks: This method provides support for backtracking algorithms by pruning permutations that cannot be completed to a solution.
member.exception: When Choices not equal to Picks.
When nodeIndex not in range (0..-1).

member.name: M:Kaos.Combinatorics.Permutation.GetRowsOfPlainChanges
member.summary: Iterate thru all rows of the table while swapping only two values in each result.
member.returns: An iterator for a table.

remarks.para: The results of this iterator are commonly known as "plain changes".

Usage note:
Using this iterator will not perform as fast as using a class that is designed and optimized for generating plain changes without the overhead of calculating the lexicographical rank for each row.

member.exception: When Choices not equal to Picks.

member.name: T:Kaos.Combinatorics.Product
member.summary: Represents a join of values taken from a supplied array of ranges.

remarks.para: A cartesian product is a set of sets where each subset is constructed by picking one element from each of a given number of sets. This process of joining elements to form new sets is repeated until all possible distinct joins are made.

The class uses an array of integers as input where each integer is the size of each of the composing sets. The joined sets are represented as rows in a table where each element is a value in the range of these supplied sizes. Rows are constructed by looping thru the rightmost ranges fastest so that the resulting table is lexicographically ordered.

Use the property to get the number of joined elements.
Use the property to get the number of distinct joins in the table.
Use the indexer to get an element of the row.
Use the default enumerator to iterate thru the elements of a row.
Use the Permute method to rearrange a supplied list based on the values in a row.

Use the property to get or set the row index in the ordered table of joins.
Use to iterate thru all possible joins of the ordered by .

The default appearance of a row is a list of integers (starting at 0) enclosed in braces. The appearance may be tailored 3 ways:
Map each element to a different value using the default enumerator or the indexer.
Use the Permute method and output the rearranged values.
Define a subclass of and override ToString().
For more information about cartesian products, see:

example.para: Iterating thru new Product (new int[] { 2, 3, 2 }).GetRows() produces:
